comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -5331,6 +5344,7 @@ static const unsigned int obj_objs[NUM_OBJ] = {
      683,    /* OBJ_X9_62_ppBasis                1 2 840 10045 1 2 3 3 */
      417,    /* OBJ_ms_csp_name                  1 3 6 1 4 1 311 17 1 */
      856,    /* OBJ_LocalKeySet                  1 3 6 1 4 1 311 17 2 */

comment.body: I didn't see this OID in http://oid-info.com/cgi-bin/display?oid=1.3.6.1.4.1.311&submit=Display&action=display but I assume it is properly assigned within MSR.

pull_request.title: Adding PQC authentication to TLS 1.3.
pull_request.body:
This adds PQC auth in TLS 1.3 to the OQS-master branch. Currently, only Picnic L1FS is supported, as it is the only available sig alg in OQS's master.

The integration follows the patterns of ec/ecx_meth.c's ED25519 and ED448 algs; there is more modified code than the KEX integration, but the code should be simpler to review. The obj_dat.h and obj_mac.h are auto-generated by some make scripts (see README.md).

I ran into an overflow problem with large Picnic cert; OpenSSL only allowed CertificateVerify messages of size 2^14, while the TLS 1.3 spec defined them with a max of 2^16 + 2. I opened an [issue](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/6433) on OpenSSL to ask about this and they confirmed this limit is artificially low to accommodate currently-supported sigs; I modified statem_[clnt/srvr].c to support larger PQC sigs.

repo.name: openssl
repo.description: Fork of OpenSSL that includes quantum-resistant algorithms and ciphersuites based on liboqs.

repo.name: openssl
repo.description: Fork of OpenSSL that includes quantum-resistant algorithms and ciphersuites based on liboqs.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -201,11 +201,15 @@
 # define SSL_aSRP                0x00000040U
 /* GOST R 34.10-2012 signature auth */
 # define SSL_aGOST12             0x00000080U
+/* OQS schemes */
+/* Picnic */
+# define SSL_aPICNICL1FS         0x00000100U
+/* ADD_MORE_OQS_SIG_HERE */
 /* Any appropriate signature auth (for TLS 1.3 ciphersuites) */
 # define SSL_aANY                0x00000000U
 /* All bits requiring a certificate */
 #define SSL_aCERT \
-    (SSL_aRSA | SSL_aDSS | SSL_aECDSA | SSL_aGOST01 | SSL_aGOST12)
+  (SSL_aRSA | SSL_aDSS | SSL_aECDSA | SSL_aGOST01 | SSL_aGOST12) /* FIXMEOQS: should I add picnic here? */
comment.body: What information do you need to make this decision?

pull_request.body:
This adds PQC auth in TLS 1.3 to the OQS-master branch. Currently, only Picnic L1FS is supported, as it is the only available sig alg in OQS's master.

The integration follows the patterns of ec/ecx_meth.c's ED25519 and ED448 algs; there is more modified code than the KEX integration, but the code should be simpler to review. The obj_dat.h and obj_mac.h are auto-generated by some make scripts (see README.md).

I ran into an overflow problem with large Picnic cert; OpenSSL only allowed CertificateVerify messages of size 2^14, while the TLS 1.3 spec defined them with a max of 2^16 + 2. I opened an [issue](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/6433) on OpenSSL to ask about this and they confirmed this limit is artificially low to accommodate currently-supported sigs; I modified statem_[clnt/srvr].c to support larger PQC sigs.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -201,11 +201,15 @@
 # define SSL_aSRP                0x00000040U
 /* GOST R 34.10-2012 signature auth */
 # define SSL_aGOST12             0x00000080U
+/* OQS schemes */
+/* Picnic */
+# define SSL_aPICNICL1FS         0x00000100U
+/* ADD_MORE_OQS_SIG_HERE */
 /* Any appropriate signature auth (for TLS 1.3 ciphersuites) */
 # define SSL_aANY                0x00000000U
 /* All bits requiring a certificate */
 #define SSL_aCERT \
-    (SSL_aRSA | SSL_aDSS | SSL_aECDSA | SSL_aGOST01 | SSL_aGOST12)
+  (SSL_aRSA | SSL_aDSS | SSL_aECDSA | SSL_aGOST01 | SSL_aGOST12) /* FIXMEOQS: should I add picnic here? */
comment.body: I looked for the use new schemes, like ED25519 and ED448; since these are not included here, I didn't add the OQS ones either. I think it's good to leave this comment in for now in the experimental OQS-master branch, and we can revisit later in an in-depth review of the code.
